questions.text: What is the defined duration for the diagnosis of acute pericarditis?
questions.solution:
Clinically, acute pericarditis is of <6 weeks duration.

Pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardial sac. This inflammation can lead to excessive secretion of the pericardial fluid leading to pericardial effusion. When the accumulation of fluid causes obstruction to the inflow of blood into the ventricles, it is called cardiac tamponade.

Clinically, pericarditis is classified as:

  • Acute - < 6 weeks
  • Subacute - 6 weeks to 6 months
  • Chronic - > 6 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with low-grade fever and severe retrosternal chest pain for 1 week. The pain got exaggerated on lying down and relieved on sitting up. On auscultation of the precordium, a grating sound was audible. Which of the given statements is false regarding this auscultatory finding?

choices.text: Best heard with the patient in left lateral position
Loudest at the lower left sternal border

questions.solution:
In this patient, Low-grade fever, chest pain that got relieved on leaning forward, and characteristic auscultatory findings are suggestive of acute pericarditis. The grating sound heard on auscultation is a pericardial friction rub.

Features of the pericardial rub:

  • Superficial scratchy/leathery/grating sound caused due to friction between the visceral and parietal pericardium
  • Best heard at end-expiration with the patient sitting and leaning forward
  • Very high-pitched sound best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope, at the lower left sternal border
  • Consists of three components corresponding to atrial systole, ventricular systole, and early ventricular diastole
  • Pathognomonic of acute pericarditis

questions.text: A young man presents to the medicine OPD with dyspnea, cough, and severe chest pain for 1 week. Chest pain is pleuritic in nature. On examination, the apical impulse is not palpable and breath sounds are normal. Which of the following is likely to be seen in the ECG of this patient?

choices.text: ST-segment elevations with a convex upward configuration
PR-segment depressions early in the disease progression
Reciprocal ST-segment depressions in all corresponding leads
T-wave inversions developing concurrently with ST-segment elevations

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of acute pericarditis. PR-segment depressions are seen early in acute pericarditis.

The ECG changes in acute pericarditis evolve through 4 stages -

  • Stage 1 - Generalized ST-segment elevation with upward concavity with reciprocal depressions only in aVR and V1 and PR segment depression. 
  • Stage 2 - The ST segments return to normal
  • Stage 3 - Diffuse T-wave inversion
  • Stage 4 - ECG returns to normal in weeks or months

ECG in acute pericarditis vs acute MI:

 

Acute pericarditis

Acute MI

Distribution of ST-segment elevations

More generalized

Limited to anterior or inferior leads because of the localized area of infarct

Morphology  of ST-segment elevations

Concave upwards

Convex upwards

Reciprocal ST-segment depressions in the opposite leads

Not present

Typically present

T-wave inversions

Only after ST-segment returns to baseline

T wave inversions can be seen even before the ST-segment returns to baseline

PR-segment

Depressed (or elevated in lead aVR) in 75% to 80% of patients

Usually not depressed (can be depressed only if concomitant atrial infarction is present).

Pathological Q-waves

Not seen

May be seen

Cardiac biomarkers are grossly elevated in acute-MI, whereas in acute pericarditis the elevation if present is only mild and indicative of epi-myocarditis causing myocyte necrosis.

questions.text: Auscultation of a patient with pleuritic chest pain revealed a patch of dullness with increased vocal fremitus beneath the angle of the left scapula. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
A patch of dullness with increased vocal fremitus beneath the angle of the left scapula due to the compression of the base of the lung by the pericardial fluid is called Ewart’s sign. It is seen in pericardial effusion.

Acute pericarditis is frequently associated with pericardial effusion.

Option A: Auenbrugger’s sign is the bulging of the epigastrium in severe pericardial effusion.

Option B: Moschcowitz’s sign is the abrupt transition in percussion from the lungs to the right heart border seen in pericardial effusion.

Option C: Dressler’s sign is the dullness to percussion of the lower half of the sternum seen in pericardial effusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Beck’s triad?
questions.solution:
Pulsus paradoxus is not part of Beck’s triad. Pulsus paradoxus is seen in cardiac tamponade. However, it is not a part of Beck's triad.

Beck’s triad is seen in cardiac tamponade and it includes: 

  • Hypotension
  • Soft or absent heart sounds
  • Jugular venous distension

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space significant enough to cause an obstruction to the inflow of blood to the ventricles. This reduces cardiac output and arterial pressure causing hypotension. 

This also causes a greater than the normal reduction in the systolic arterial blood pressure producing pulsus paradoxus. Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration.

Other causes of pulsus paradoxus include:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Severe obstructive lung disease
  • Hemorrhagic shock

The echocardiography clip below shows the swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Which of the following is a differentiating feature between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
The differentiating feature between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax is breath sounds. The breath sounds are absent in tension pneumothorax while they are present in cardiac tamponade.

The presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and muffled heart sounds (Beck's triad) suggest a cardiac tamponade. These features can also be seen in tension pneumothorax. Other clinical features pointing towards tension pneumothorax are absent breath sounds, hyper resonance to percussion, and shift of the mediastinum to the contralateral side. 

Heart sounds can be muffled by structures between the stethoscope and the heart, eg, adipose tissue deposition (obesity), fluid accumulation (pericardial effusion, pleural effusion), gas accumulation (pneumothorax, subcutaneous emphysema), soft tissue masses can lead to attenuation of heart sounds.

questions.text: An intern is asked to measure the blood pressure of a patient with cardiac tamponade. He/she should ask the patient to:
questions.solution:
The patient with cardiac tamponade is asked to breathe normally to elicit pulsus paradoxus.

In a patient with cardiac tamponade, both ventricles share an incompressible pericardial covering due to the fluid. As the right ventricle enlarges during inspiration, the interventricular septum bulges into the left ventricle, reducing the left ventricular volume.

This results in reduced stroke volume and hence reduced systolic arterial pressure. 
As a result, there is a greater than normal (more than 10 mmHg) fall in systolic arterial blood pressure during inspiration, producing pulsus paradoxus.

This cannot be elicited if the patient is holding his/her breath, taking long or shallow breaths.

Pulsus paradoxus is also seen with effusive constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy and right ventricular myocardial infarction.

Related Pearl: Causes of Pulsus Paradoxus

Physiological causes

Obesity

Pregnancy

Cardiovascular causes

Cardiac tamponade – most common cause

Constrictive pericarditis ( in 1/3rd cases )

Massive pulmonary embolism

Severe CCF

Hypovolemic shock

Respiratory causes

Severe obstructive lung disease

Acute severe asthma

Severe emphysema

Tension pneumothorax

questions.text:
An RTA victim is brought with breathing difficulty. On examination, the following is noted. Which of the following JVP findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
  • BP- 80/58mmHg
  • Pulse- feeble
  • JVP- elevated
  • Heart sounds- muffled

choices.text: Absent x and prominent y descent
Prominent x and absent y descent

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated JVP (Beck's triad) suggest a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. The JVP finding most likely to be seen is prominent x descent and absent y descent.

 

Note: JVP in constrictive pericarditis is characterized by prominent x and y descents.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A patient with dizziness and breathing difficulty came to the emergency department. The ECG is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia. This along with the patient's symptoms suggests a likely diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

Electrical alternans is the beat-to-beat alternation in the ECG waveform. In cardiac tamponade, this is caused by the periodic swinging motion of the heart in a large pericardial effusion.

Feature  Cardiac tamponade Constrictive pericarditis Restrictive cardiomyopathy
 Pulsus paradoxus +++ + +/- (Rare)

JVP

 

Prominent x descent

Prominent y descent - ++ +
Kussmaul's sign -  + +/- (Rare)
Pericardial knock - ++ -
Third heart sound - - +
Electrical alternans ++ - -
Thickened and calcified pericardium - +++ -

questions.text: A 25-year-old road traffic accident victim presents with chest pain and breathlessness. On examination, his BP was 80/60mmHg.On inspection, his neck veins were distended and on auscultation, his heart sounds were muffled. Which of the following clinical features is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and signs suggest a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. Out of the given features, pulsus paradoxus is seen in cardiac tamponade.

questions.text:
A young motorist sustained injuries in a road traffic accident. He was found to have fractures of multiple ribs anteriorly on both sides. Radial and femoral fractures were also present. On examination, the following was noted. What should be the immediate intervention?
  • Blood pressure- 80/60 mmHg
  • Heart rate- 140/min 
  • Respiratory rate- tachypnea
  • General state: agitated and restless
  • Jugular veins- distended
  • Respiratory system- B/L equal and adequate air entry
  • CVS- heart sounds barely audible. Femoral pulse weakly palpable. Distal pulses not felt

choices.text: Intercostal tube drainage on both sides

questions.solution:
The presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and absence of heart sounds (Beck's triad) are suggestive of cardiac tamponade. An urgent pericardial tap needs to be done to relieve the tension on the heart chambers.

Although these features could be seen in tension pneumothorax as well, the presence of adequate bilateral air entry excludes this diagnosis.

Pericardiocentesis, also known as pericardial tap, can be performed with sub-xiphoid, parasternal, or apical approaches. The most common approach is a sub-xiphoid approach under echocardiographic guidance.

Option A: Rapid blood transfusion is needed in massive blood loss indicated by hypotension. Although this patient presents with hypotension, it is most likely a result of cardiac tamponade. Although blood transfusion is indicated, it will be effective only when the pericardial tap decompresses the pericardium.

Option C: Intercostal tube drainage is done in tension pneumothorax. The presence of adequate air entry bilaterally excludes this diagnosis.

Option D: The fixation of femur fracture and femoral artery is not a priority here. The inability to palpate pulses distal to the fracture could be a result of hypotension. This needs to be explored only if the patient fails to improve after the pericardial tap and blood transfusion.

questions.text: You're an intern examining a patient in the ICU. While assessing the JVP, you notice a lack of fall during inspiration. Which of the following conditions would you not consider as a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A rise or a lack of fall in JVP with inspiration is known as Kussmaul's sign. It is not seen in cardiac tamponade.

Normally, in inspiration due to the negative intrathoracic pressure and increased intrathoracic volume, the capacity of the right heart increases and the JVP falls. In conditions where the myocardium or pericardium is poorly compliant, it does not allow the right heart chambers to accommodate more blood and this fall is not seen. In fact, due to an increase in venous return during inspiration, the JVP might rise. This is called Kussmaul's sign.

This is seen in:

  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Right ventricular infarcts
  • Advanced cases of left ventricular systolic failure

Kussmaul’s sign is not seen in patients with cardiac tamponade because even though the increase in pericardial pressure exerts an inward force compressing the entire heart during inspiration, the increase in negative intrathoracic pressure is still transmitted to the right side of the heart. This allows for an increase in blood flow to the right atrium. Therefore, the JVP falls as seen in normal conditions.

Feature  Cardiac tamponade Constrictive pericarditis Restrictive cardiomyopathy
 Pulsus paradoxus +++ + +/- (Rare)

JVP

 

Prominent x descent

 +++ ++ +++
Prominent y descent - ++ +
Kussmaul's sign -  +++    +/- (Rare)
Pericardial knock - ++ -
Third heart sound - - +
Electrical alternans ++ - -
Thickened and calcified pericardium - +++ -

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step?

choices.text: Start IV fluids with large bore cannula
Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
Take the patient to the ICU and intubate him

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young male developing respiratory distress with hypotension, subcutaneous emphysema, and unilaterally absent air entry is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The immediate next step, in this case, would be needle decompression at the fifth intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line (as the patient is an adult). 

In children, the second intercostal space in the midclavicular line is chosen as the site for needle decompression.

Needle decompression turns a tension pneumothorax into an open pneumothorax. It has to be followed by tube thoracostomy. An intercostal chest drain (ICD) tube is inserted in the triangle of safety, just anterior to the midaxillary line on the side of the lung injury. The site of insertion is the same in both children and adults.

The triangle of safety is bounded by the lateral border of the pectoralis major anteriorly, the anterior border of the latissimus dorsi posteriorly, and the fifth intercostal space inferiorly, with the apex below the axilla. This provides a safe landmark for the insertion of an ICD with minimal risk of tissue injury. 

Tension pneumothorax is a condition where air accumulates in the pleural space due to a one-way valve air leak, leading to the collapse of the affected lung. This can cause a mediastinal shift, compression of the opposite lung, and decreased venous return, resulting in obstructive shock. It commonly occurs during positive-pressure mechanical ventilation, but can also happen after chest trauma, subclavian/internal jugular venous catheter insertion, or chest wall defects. The diagnosis is clinical, and immediate treatment is necessary without waiting for radiological confirmation.

Tension pneumothorax is characterized by chest pain, tachypnoea, tachycardia, hypotension, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, absent breath sounds on the affected side, cyanosis, and neck vein distention. Patients can also develop subcutaneous emphysema as a complication secondary to the pneumothorax.
